title: Dakgalbi (Spicy Chicken)
description: Dakgalbi is a fiery Korean stir-fry of boneless chicken marinated in a gochujang-based sauce and cooked with cabbage, sweet potatoes and rice cakes until caramelized. It delivers a balance of spicy, sweet and savory flavors with a slightly charred, chewy texture from high-heat pan-frying.

ingredients.display_name: boneless skinless chicken thighs, trimmed and bite-size

ingredients.notes: use rice syrup for traditional sheen

ingredients.display_name: gochugaru (Korean chili flakes) or extra chili flakes
korean rice cakes (garlic tteok / cylinder type), soaked if refrigerated
ingredients.notes: soak 10–20 minutes in warm water if hard

ingredients.display_name: sweet potato, peeled and sliced into 5 mm rounds
cooking water or low-sodium chicken stock

steps.text: Prepare ingredients: trim and cut chicken into bite-size pieces, slice cabbage and onion, peel and slice sweet potato, julienne carrot if using, slice scallions, soak rice cakes if refrigerated until pliable.
Make the marinade: in a bowl combine gochujang, soy sauce, rice syrup (or honey), gochugaru, minced garlic, grated ginger, sesame oil, granulated sugar and ground black pepper; whisk until smooth.

Toss chicken with about two-thirds of the marinade in a mixing bowl and let marinate briefly at room temperature while you preheat the pan (10–20 minutes is fine for quick recipes; longer for deeper flavor).

Heat a large heavy-bottomed skillet or cast-iron pan over medium-high heat and add vegetable oil. Add marinated chicken in a single layer and sear, stirring occasionally, until pieces begin to brown but are not fully cooked through.

Add sliced onion, sweet potato rounds and the reserved marinade; stir to coat. Pour a small amount of water or stock to create a saucy base and cover for a couple minutes to allow sweet potatoes to soften.

Uncover and add cabbage, soaked rice cakes and carrots; toss to combine and continue cooking over medium-high heat, stirring frequently so the sauce reduces and lightly caramelizes onto the chicken and vegetables.

Continue cooking until rice cakes are chewy-tender, sweet potatoes are cooked through, and sauce is glossy and slightly reduced. Adjust seasoning with remaining marinade if more heat or sauce is desired and toss to finish.

Finish: toss in sliced scallions and toasted sesame seeds, drizzle a little extra sesame oil if desired, then transfer to a serving platter or serve directly from the pan with steamed rice or lettuce for wrapping.
